Package com.rb.nonbiz.types

Class PreciseValue<T extends PreciseValue<T>>

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
com.rb.nonbiz.types.RBNumeric<T>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.PreciseValue<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Money, MoneyFraction, MoneySignedFraction, MoneyUnitFraction, OnesBasedReturn, Price, RationalUnitFraction, SignedFraction, SignedMoney, SignedQuantity, SplitMultiplier, UnitFraction
public abstract class PreciseValue<T extends PreciseValue<T>>
extends RBNumeric<T>
A base class for creating typesafe versions of an BigDecimal, with two goals: tightening semantics, and making code easier to read. A PreciseValue is the base class of many value classes in the code.

This exists because using a plain double may result in an approximate value. E.g. 100.00 could be represented internally as 99.99999999999999. A BigDecimal avoids that.

Another advantage of using PreciseValue is that it lets us have more clearly named comparison methods:

val1.isLessThan(val2)

is clearer than

val1.compareTo(val2) < 0
See Also:
Serialized Form

    • snapToZero

      public static java.math.BigDecimal snapToZero​(java.math.BigDecimal unsnapped)
      If very near 0, return 0, otherwise return whatever number was passed.

      This is useful e.g. for results of subtraction of 2 quantities that can be slightly off because of numeric reasons.

    • snapToZero

      public static <T extends PreciseValue<T>> java.math.BigDecimal snapToZero​(T unsnapped)
      If very near 0, return 0, otherwise return whatever number was passed.

      This is useful e.g. for results of subtraction of 2 quantities that can be slightly off because of numeric reasons.

    • almostEquals

      public <S extends T> boolean almostEquals​(S other, Epsilon epsilon)
      Assuming it's possible to do so and not restricted by the generics mechanism (e.g. a comparison between Money and BuyQuantity), this will compare the BigDecimal values.

      There's a few cases where this is counterintuitive, e.g. buyQuantity(10).almostEquals(sellQuantity(10), 1e-8) is true. The upside is fewer conversions and fewer cases where we have an unexpected result because we forgot to do some conversion.

    • preciseValuesAlmostEqual

      public static <V extends PreciseValue<V>> boolean preciseValuesAlmostEqual​(V v1, V v2, Epsilon epsilon)

    • isSafelyLessThan

      public boolean isSafelyLessThan​(T other, Epsilon epsilon)
      PreciseValues may be precise, but the process that generates them may not be. We often want to check that e.g. the quantity to trade is less than some upper bound. For numerical reasons, given how quantities are generated off he output of the optimizer, it is possible that it is 'functionally equal' to its upper bound, but just epsilon above it. In those cases, we want to use #isSafelyLessThan with a tiny epsilon

      Note that there is no isSafelyLessThanOrEqualTo; once we start adding a double non-zero epsilon, that itself will cause some tiny numerical inaccuracy, so it doesn't make sense to do equality comparisons.

    • isSafelyGreaterThan

      public boolean isSafelyGreaterThan​(T other, Epsilon epsilon)
      See Also:
      isSafelyLessThan(T, com.rb.nonbiz.types.Epsilon)

    • coarseScaleRoundingSameAsFineScale

      public boolean coarseScaleRoundingSameAsFineScale​(RoundingScale roundingScaleCoarse, RoundingScale roundingScaleFine)
      Check if the BigDecimal is rounded to the same number using two different rounding scales.

      The purpose is to see if the number has been "rounded enough" to the coarse scale. E.g. 12.30001 is "pretty close" to being rounded to 0.1.

      This rounds the BigDecimal to both the first ('coarse') and to the second ('fine') rounding scales, and compares the two rounded versions. It they match, then 'true' is returned (otherwise 'false').

    • isExactlyRound

      public boolean isExactlyRound()
      Returns true if this is a round number, and not just round subject to epsilon.

    • signsAreOpposite

      public static <T extends PreciseValue<T>> boolean signsAreOpposite​(PreciseValue<T> item1, PreciseValue<T> item2)
      Returns true if we pass in a positive and a negative number. If either is 0, then this also always returns false.

    • signsAreSame

      public static boolean signsAreSame​(PreciseValue<?> item1, PreciseValue<?> item2)
      Returns true if positive AND positive, negative AND negative, or zero AND zero.
